properties.name: City Center
properties.description: The center of downtoan is Grand Rapids' thriving business and cultural district. Its most recognizable landmark is Alexander Calder's La Grande Vitesse - the first NEA-funded public work. If you're in the area, you can't miss it, in the large plaza outside the country and city buildings.

properties.name: HeartSide
properties.description: Originally considered the "heart" of the city thanks to the railroad depot that brought so many to Grand Rapids, Heartside has become a central depot for local artists.

properties.name: Hillside
properties.description: Known for its large Victorian homes, and home to the city's library, theater and two colleges, Hillside recently received the nickname "Pill Hill," due to the considerable medical investment and infrastructure currently underway.

properties.name: Monroe North / Belknap
properties.description: A turn-of-the-century industrial hub, many of Monroe North's former factories have been revamped into upscales living. The neighborhood is highly walkable and a lot of fun in the evening. Climb the pedestrian stairs on North Division Avenue to get a great view of the city from Belknap Lookout Park.

properties.name: WestSide
properties.description: Originally a working-class settlement, the Westside of the Grand River is now home to up-and-coming neighborhoods, as well as GrandValley State University's downtown campus, two public museums, and a myriad of parks that offer a beautiful sculpture exhibition along the riverNeighborhood Day Info
